  1. Data Type

    1. Primitive types

      No unsigned number in java

      Primitive typeSizeBoxing classComments
      byte1 byteByte
      short2 bytesShort
      char2 bytesCharacter'' 一撇在java里是char不是string
      int4 bytesInteger1). int cannot be used as boolean. 2). Integer.MAX_VALUE = 2147483647
      long8 bytesLong
      float4 bytesFloat±3.40282347E+38F, IEEE 754 specification
      double8 bytesDouble±1.79769313486231570E+308
      booleanIt's virtual machine dependentBoolean

    2. Attention

                                      public class DataType {
                                    public static void main(String [] args){
                                        char q = 113, n = 110, comma = 44;
                                        System.out.println(q + ',' + n); // print 267; because it first evaluate q + ',' + n => 113 + 110 + 44 = 267. And addition of char will generate integer type.
                                        System.out.println(comma); 
                                    }
                                }

      The result of adding Java chars, shorts, or bytes is an int. If any of the operands is of a reference type, unboxing conversion (§5.1.8) is performed. Then: If either operand is of type double, the other is converted to double. Otherwise, if either operand is of type float, the other is converted to float. Otherwise, if either operand is of type long, the other is converted to long. Otherwise, both operands are converted to type int.

    3. Binary Operator

      0x00 hex, 011 (oct), 0b11 (binary) 123 (dec)

      int 32-bit (2's complement): 0xff ff ff ff = -1; 0x80 00 00 00 = -2147483648 MIN; 0x7f ff ff ff = 2147483647 MAX;

      ^ XOR, | OR, & AND, ~ NOT Any number except 0 does ~ will generate 0. ~0 generates 1

    4. Java uses Unicode + UTF-16 encoding

      Unicode defines the translation from number to character. e.g. 113 is q ... UTF-8/UTF-16 defines how to store and interpert this number. For example, Both uft-8 and utf-16 use 113 to represent q. But utf-8 only use 1 byte to store q, utf-16 use 2 bytes.

  2. Object

    Java supports pre-defined primitive types, class (concrete & abstract), interface, enum, but not C# struct and delegate

    All classes in java inherit from Object class.

    1. Inside Object

                         package java.lang;
                   public class Object {
                       private static native void registerNatives();
                       static {
                           registerNatives();
                       }
                       public final native Class<?> getClass();
                       public native int hashCode();
                       public boolean equals(Object obj) {
                           return (this == obj);
                       }
                       protected native Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException;
                       public String toString() {
                           return getClass().getName() + "@" + Integer.toHexString(hashCode());
                       }
                       public final native void notify();
                       public final native void notifyAll();
                       public final native void wait(long timeout) throws InterruptedException;
                       public final void wait(long timeout, int nanos) throws InterruptedException {
                           if (timeout < 0) {
                               throw new IllegalArgumentException("timeout value is negative");
                           }
                           if (nanos < 0 || nanos > 999999) {
                               throw new IllegalArgumentException(
                                                   "nanosecond timeout value out of range");
                           }
                           if (nanos > 0) {
                               timeout++;
                           }
                           wait(timeout);
                       }
                       public final void wait() throws InterruptedException {
                           wait(0);
                       }
                       protected void finalize() throws Throwable { }
                   }

    2. finalize

  3. java.util.Date

    1. Classes

      DateFormat: format and parse date strings.
      Calender: It tolerates the problem of difference of time zone.

      Knowledge about time

      UTC (Coordinated Universal Time): the most accurate time in the world. It use atomic clock combined with the Earth rotation. For example, UTC considered "leap second".
      GMT (Greenwich mean time): the civil name of UTC. They are same.
      Modern OS assume 1 day = 24 * 60 * 60 seconds in all case. Therefore, OS is not always accurate. Moreover, JVM is based on OS. Therefore JVM is not accurate.

    2. Date

      It includes year, month, day, hour, minute, second, millisecond

                      new Date() // initialize it at which it is allocated.
                new Date(long time) // time in millisecond + 1970.1.1 00:00:00 GMT
                .getTime() // long: Returns the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT.
                .toString() // String:

  4. String

    String is immutable, so when you want to dynamically create String, use StringBuffer.
    String name = "Nan Qin";
    Constructors// String(byte [], Charset)
    .charAt(int index): char char in Java is 2-byte
    + / .concat(String str); return a new string, the original string does not change.
    .hashCode() :int
    .length(): int // Array's length is not a function but an attributes.
    .toLowerCase();
    .toUpperCase();
    .substring(int beginindex);
    .substring(int beginindex, int endindex);

    StringBuffer

    Essential method, append/insert
    new StringBuffer();
    new StringBuffer(int initialCapa);
    new StringBuffer(String str);

    append(any type): //append any type, internally call .toString();
    insert(int offset, any type); // insert at the offset index, not after
    length();
    .toString();
    .reverse(): StringBuffer; the original does not change, return a new StringBuffer

  5. Array

    1. Array must has at least one layer is initialized as declaration.

            int [][] a = new int[2][2];
        int [][] b = new int[10][];
        for(int i = 0 ; i < 10; i++){
            b[i] = new int[i];
        }

    2. Array init 

                    int [] a = {1,2,3};
                int [] a1 = new int[]{1,2,3};
                // wrong int [] b = new int[3]{1,2,3};

    Arrays

    Defined by java.util.*, so import it before using

    Arrays is a class (not String [], int [])

    1.n*log(n)Arrays.sort(int [])... // float [], ..., in-place sort, return void., default increasing order.
    Arrays.sort(int [], int from, int to)
    Arrays.sort(int [], Comparator) // customized sort 

                    class NameComparator implements Comparator<String> 
                {          
                    public int compare(String a, String b) 
                    { 
                        return a.length() - b.length(); 
                    } 
                }


    2.Print services: Default print array will print its address ..., Use Arrays.toString(int []) convert.
    It is not recursive, which means a 2 dimension array not work well.

    3. Array copy 
                int [] a = new int[10];
            for(){
                // init a
            }
            int [] b = Arrays.copyOf(a, 2 * a.length); // increase the length of a. 
            // remaining is filled with 0, or false.
